europeana:record.dc:title: New discoveries from old sources, with reference to the original bird and mammal fauna of the Mascarene Islands, Indian Ocean
Zoologische Mededelingen
europeana:record.dc:creator: Hume J.P.
Prys-Jones R.P.
europeana:record.dc:subject: Aves
Mascarene Islands
extinct birds
iconographical evidence
journals
diaries
museum specimens

loans and exchanges
europeana:record.dc:description: The faunal history of the Mascarene Islands (Mauritius, RÃ©union and Rodrigues) has been extensively documented, with most information being derived from the fossil record, museum skins, the journals and logbooks of early mariners and contemporary illustrations. However, our research on original sources, including Dutch journals held at The Hague, and archival correspondence and fossil collections, notably at The Natural History Museum, London, and the University Museum of Zoology, Cambridge, indicates that many problems remain to be resolved. This situation has been exacerbated by exchange schemes amongst museums, personal rivalries, misidentification, lack of comparative material, and inadequate provenance of specimens; furthermore, problematic and unidentifiable fossil remains have been ignored or lumped with other species. Among other topics, new information is presented on the discovery of the famous Mare aux Songes fossil deposit on Mauritius. The Mascarene Islands epitomize the potential for new discoveries from old collections, even within the largest and most modern institutions.
